expert.help: Compare the CQA-computed load/store/compute metrics with the capacity of the core. For instance if CQA computes 24 bytes in the loop in 2 cycles (that is 12 cycles per cycle) and if the core can process up to 16 bytes per cycle, that metric is 75%.
expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 13.17 cycles. At this rate:
  • 12% of peak load performance is reached (12.15 out of 96.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
  • 15% of peak store performance is reached (10.03 out of 64.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

expert.title: Front-end bottlenecks
expert.txt:
Performance is limited by instruction throughput (loading/decoding program instructions to execution core) (front-end is a bottleneck).

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 13.17 to 12.00 cycles (1.10x speedup).

header:
Warnings:
The number of fused uops of the instruction [CLTQ] is unknown
0% of peak computational performance is used (0.08 out of 24.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
• Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
  • Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
  • To reference allocatable arrays, use "allocatable" instead of "pointer" pointers or qualify them with the "contiguous" attribute (Fortran 2008)
  • For structures, limit to one indirection. For example, use a_b%c instead of a%b%c with a_b set to a%b before this loop
gain.title: Code clean check
gain.txt:
Detected a slowdown caused by scalar integer instructions (typically used for address computation).
By removing them, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 13.17 to 3.67 cycles (3.59x speedup).

gain.workaround:
• Try another compiler or update/tune your current one
  • Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
    • If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly: Fortran storage order is column-major: do i do j a(i,j) = b(i,j) (slow, non stride 1) => do i do j a(j,i) = b(i,j) (fast, stride 1)<>
    • If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA): do i a(i)%x = b(i)%x (slow, non stride 1) => do i a%x(i) = b%x(i) (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
Store and arithmetical SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is probably not vectorized.
Only 11% of vector register length is used (average across all SSE/AVX instructions).
By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 13.17 to 2.15 cycles (6.14x speedup).

gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt: Found no such bottlenecks but see expert reports for more complex bottlenecks.

Warnings:
The number of fused uops of the instruction [CLTQ] is unknown
0% of peak computational performance is used (0.08 out of 24.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
• Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
  • Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
  • To reference allocatable arrays, use "allocatable" instead of "pointer" pointers or qualify them with the "contiguous" attribute (Fortran 2008)
  • For structures, limit to one indirection. For example, use a_b%c instead of a%b%c with a_b set to a%b before this loop
gain.title: Code clean check
gain.txt:
Detected a slowdown caused by scalar integer instructions (typically used for address computation).
By removing them, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 13.17 to 3.67 cycles (3.59x speedup).

gain.workaround:
• Try another compiler or update/tune your current one
  • Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
    • If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly: Fortran storage order is column-major: do i do j a(i,j) = b(i,j) (slow, non stride 1) => do i do j a(j,i) = b(i,j) (fast, stride 1)<>
    • If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA): do i a(i)%x = b(i)%x (slow, non stride 1) => do i a%x(i) = b%x(i) (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
Store and arithmetical SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is probably not vectorized.
Only 11% of vector register length is used (average across all SSE/AVX instructions).
By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 13.17 to 2.15 cycles (6.14x speedup).

gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt: Found no such bottlenecks but see expert reports for more complex bottlenecks.

The presence of multiple execution paths is typically the main/first bottleneck. Try to simplify control inside loop: ideally, try to remove all conditional expressions, for example by (if applicable):

  • turning them into conditional moves, MIN or MAX
